description: From Middle English bikeren (“to attack”), from Middle Dutch bicken (“to stab, thrust, attack”)  +‎ -er (frequentative suffix), from Proto-Germanic *bikjaną (compare Old English becca (“pickax”), Dutch bikken (“to hack”), German picken (“to peck, pick at”), Old Norse bikkja (“to plunge into water”)), from Proto-Indo-European *bʰeg- (“to smash, break”). Compare also German Low German bickern (“to nibble, gnaw”).

entries.meaning: (Scotland, obsolete) A fight with stones between two parties of boys.
A wrangle; also, a noise, as in angry contention.
The process by which selective eating clubs at Princeton University choose new members.

verbs.description: bicker (third-person singular simple present bickers, present participle bickering, simple past and past participle bickered)

entries.meaning: To quarrel in a tiresome, insulting manner.
examples: They bickered about dinner every evening.

entries.meaning: To brawl or move tremulously, quiver, shimmer (of a water stream, light, flame, etc.)
examples: I come from haunts of coot and hern, / I make a sudden sally, / And sparkle out among the fern, / To bicker down a valley.

entries.meaning: To skirmish; to exchange blows; to fight.

description: From Scots bicker, from Middle English biker. Doublet of beaker.

entries.meaning: (Scotland) A wooden drinking-cup or other dish.
examples: …the liquors were handed around in great fulness, the ale in large wooden bickers, and the brandy in capacious horns of oxen.
